details.title: Stochastic degradation models with several accelerating variables
details.standardTitle: Stochastic degradation models with several accelerating variables

p: Chanseok Park is an Assistant Professor of Mathematical Sciences at Clemson University, Clemson, SC. He received his B.S. in Mechanical Engineering from Seoul National University, his M.A. in Mathematics from the University of Texas at Austin, and his Ph.D. in Statistics in 2000 from the Pennsylvania State University. His research interests include minimum distance estimation, survival analysis, statistical computing & simulation, acoustics, and solid mechanics.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. Sci., Clemson Univ., SC, USA
authors.name: C. Park

p: William J. Padgett is a Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Statistics at the University of South Carolina, Columbia; and a Visiting Professor of Mathematical Sciences at Clemson University, Clemson, SC. He received his Ph.D. in Statistics in 1971 from Virginia Polytechnic Institute & State University. He has published numerous papers on nonparametric & parametric inference in reliability theory & applications, and on other topics in statistics & probability. He has been an Associate Editor for Journal of Statistical Theory and Applications, Journal of Nonparametric Statistics, and Lifetime Data Analysis, among other journals; and has served as a Coordinating Editor for Journal of Statistical Planning and Inference. He is a Member of the International Statistical Institute; and is a Fellow of the American Statistical Association, and of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics.

details.abstract: Many products & systems age, wear, or degrade over time before they fail or break down. Thus, in many engineering reliability experiments, measures of degradation or wear toward failure can often be observed over a period of time before failure occurs. Because the degradation values provide additional information beyond that provided by the failure observations, both sets of observations need to be considered when doing inference on the statistical parameters of the product or system lifetime distributions. For highly-reliable modern products, it often takes much more time to obtain lifetime & degradation data under usual use conditions, and this requires one to use accelerated tests. Accelerated tests expose the products to greater environmental stress levels so that we can obtain lifetime & degradation measurements in a more timely fashion. In addition, many products are exposed to several environmental variables in some manufacturing processes, or under some operating conditions. This motivates the need for developing general accelerated test models with several accelerating variables for inference based on both observed failure values, and degradation measurements. In this paper, new accelerated test models are developed based on a generalized cumulative damage approach with a stochastic process characterizing a degradation phenomenon.

citations.title: Stochastic degradation models with several accelerating variables

context.text: Classical accelerated test models in engineering, such as the power rule or Arrhenius reaction rate models, are based on one acceleration variable, or perhaps two variables as in the case of the generalized Eyring model [1].

Other specific link functions have been developed for two accelerating variables, such as the generalized Eyring relationship model [1], but are of somewhat limited use for specific physical situations.

references.title: The Theory of Rate Processes
references.text: S. Glasstone, K. J. Laidler, H. E. Eyring, The Theory of Rate Processes, 1941, McGraw-Hill.

context.text: In particular, Nelson [2]–[4] references results on degradation models & accelerated tests up to that time, while the books by Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [5], and Meeker & Escobar [6] discuss more recent work.
For more details about accelerated tests with the link functions, the reader is referred to Nelson [2], Meeker & Escobar [6], Mann [30], and other references therein.

references.title: Accelerated Testing: Statistical Models, Test Plans, and Data Analyses
references.text: W. Nelson, Accelerated Testing: Statistical Models Test Plans and Data Analyses, 1990, John Wiley & Sons.

links.abstract: This article provides a current bibliography of 159 references on statistical plans for accelerated tests. It will aid practitioners in selecting plans, and will stimulate researchers to develop needed plans & software.

context.text: In particular, Nelson [2]–[3][4] references results on degradation models & accelerated tests up to that time, while the books by Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [5], and Meeker & Escobar [6] discuss more recent work.

A bibliography of accelerated
test plans
references.text: W. Nelson, "A bibliography of accelerated test plans", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 54, pp. 194-197, 2005.

links.abstract: This is the bibliography referenced in the article by Wayne B Nelson titled "A bibliography of accelerated test plans," published in the IEEE Transactions on Reliability June 2005 issue (vol.54, no.2, ISSN 0018-9529).

context.text: In particular, Nelson [2]–[4] references results on degradation models & accelerated tests up to that time, while the books by Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [5], and Meeker & Escobar [6] discuss more recent work.

A bibliography of accelerated
test plans part II—references
references.text: W. Nelson, "A bibliography of accelerated test plans part II—references", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 54, pp. 370-373, 2005.

context.text: In particular, Nelson [2]–[4] references results on degradation models & accelerated tests up to that time, while the books by Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [5], and Meeker & Escobar [6] discuss more recent work.

references.title: Accelerated Life Models, Modeling and Statistical Analysis
references.text: V. Bagdonavicius, M. Nikulin, Accelerated Life Models Modeling and Statistical Analysis, 2002, Chapman & Hall/CRC.

context.text: In particular, Nelson [2]–[4] references results on degradation models & accelerated tests up to that time, while the books by Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [5], and Meeker & Escobar [6] discuss more recent work.

Regression-type methods to fit general degradation path models & special cases were used by several authors, including Meeker & Escobar [6], Lu & Meeker [17], Boulanger & Escobar [18], Hamada [19], and Meeker [20].
Some engineering applications of degradation models with accelerated testing have been considered by Meeker & Escobar [6], Carey & Koenig [21], and Yanagisawa [22].
For more details about accelerated tests with the link functions, the reader is referred to Nelson [2], Meeker & Escobar [6], Mann [30], and other references therein.
The data set in this example was generated by extending the carbon-film-resistor problem from Shiomi & Yanagisawa [40], and Meeker & Escobar [6].
The original data in [6], [40] have one accelerating variable (temperature).

references.title: Statistical Methods for Reliability Data
references.text: W. Q. Meeker, L. A. Escobar, Statistical Methods for Reliability Data, 1998, John Wiley & Sons.

context.text: Degradation models based on Gaussian or related processes have been proposed by Doksum & Normand [7], Lu [8], Whitmore [9], Whitmore & Schenkelberg [10], Whitmore [11], Pettit & Young [12], Padgett & Tomlinson [13], and Park & Padgett [14].

references.title:
Gaussian models for degradation processes—part I:
methods for the analysis of biomarker data
references.text: K. Doksum, S.-L. T. Normand, "Gaussian models for degradation processes—part I: methods for the analysis of biomarker data", Lifetime Data Analysis, vol. 1, pp. 135-144, 1995.

context.text: Degradation models based on Gaussian or related processes have been proposed by Doksum & Normand [7], Lu [8], Whitmore [9], Whitmore & Schenkelberg [10], Whitmore [11], Pettit & Young [12], Padgett & Tomlinson [13], and Park & Padgett [14].

Park & Padgett [14] extended the accelerated degradation models (for a single accelerating variable) to a very general class of models that included Gaussian process models (Lu [8], and Padgett & Tomlinson [13]), geometric Brownian motion models, and gamma process models (Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [15], and Lawless & Crowder [16]) as special cases.

For example, taking \$D_{u}\$ to be a Brownian motion process with \$h(u)=1\$ & \$c(u)=u\$ gives a degradation model based on a Gaussian process, as studied by Lu [8], Pettit & Young [12], and Padgett & Tomlinson [13].
Analogous to the approach of Lu [8], we let \$A\$ denote the event that \$X_{t}=x\$ does not exceed the threshold, and \$B\$ (or \$A^{c}\$) be the event that \$X_{t}=x\$ passes the threshold.
Using a result of Lu [8], we have  It follows that  where \$-\infty<x<C\$.

references.text: J. Lu, Degradation Processes and Related Reliability Models, 1995, McGill University.

context.text: Degradation models based on Gaussian or related processes have been proposed by Doksum & Normand [7], Lu [8], Whitmore [9], Whitmore & Schenkelberg [10], Whitmore [11], Pettit & Young [12], Padgett & Tomlinson [13], and Park & Padgett [14].

context.text: Degradation models based on Gaussian or related processes have been proposed by Doksum & Normand [7], Lu [8], Whitmore [9], Whitmore & Schenkelberg [10], Whitmore [11], Pettit & Young [12], Padgett & Tomlinson [13], and Park & Padgett [14].

Park & Padgett [14] extended the accelerated degradation models (for a single accelerating variable) to a very general class of models that included Gaussian process models (Lu [8], and Padgett & Tomlinson [13]), geometric Brownian motion models, and gamma process models (Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [15], and Lawless & Crowder [16]) as special cases.

For example, taking \$D_{u}\$ to be a Brownian motion process with \$h(u)=1\$ & \$c(u)=u\$ gives a degradation model based on a Gaussian process, as studied by Lu [8], Pettit & Young [12], and Padgett & Tomlinson [13].
This degradation model was proposed by Padgett & Tomlinson [13].

The model based on the Brownian motion process proposed by Padgett & Tomlinson [13] can also be of this form.
It should be noted again that Padgett & Tomlinson [13], and Park & Padgett [14] used \$f_{A}(\cdot)\$ instead of \$f(\cdot\vert A)\$ by ignoring \$P(A)\$ as mentioned before.
For example, asymptotic confidence bounds for quantiles of the distribution of the first passage time can be found by the same method used by Padgett & Tomlinson [13], and Durham & Padgett [23].

references.title:
Inference from accelerated degradation and failure data
based on Gaussian process models
references.text: W. J. Padgett, M. A. Tomlinson, "Inference from accelerated degradation and failure data based on Gaussian process models", Lifetime Data Analysis, vol. 10, pp. 191-206, 2004.

context.text: Degradation models based on Gaussian or related processes have been proposed by Doksum & Normand [7], Lu [8], Whitmore [9], Whitmore & Schenkelberg [10], Whitmore [11], Pettit & Young [12], Padgett & Tomlinson [13], and Park & Padgett [14].

Park & Padgett [14] extended the accelerated degradation models (for a single accelerating variable) to a very general class of models that included Gaussian process models (Lu [8], and Padgett & Tomlinson [13]), geometric Brownian motion models, and gamma process models (Bagdonavicius & Nikulin [15], and Lawless & Crowder [16]) as special cases.
In the present paper, we extend Park & Padgett [14] to the case of accelerated test models with \$k\geq 1\$ accelerating variables.

In this paper, following Park & Padgett [14] to obtain two further basic degradation models, we consider \$c(u)=\log u\$ & \$h(u)=1\$ with a Brownian motion process \$D_{u}\$, which results in a geometric Brownian motion process model for the degradation process \$X_{t}\$, and also take \$c(u)=u\$ & \$h(u)=1\$ with a gamma process \$D_{u}\$.
Several acceleration variables will be incorporated into the models in Section V, extending the results of Park & Padgett [14].
For more details, refer to Park & Padgett [14].
This degradation model was proposed by Park & Padgett [14].
The conditional pdf given the event \$A\$ is  where  Note that Park & Padgett [14] ignore \$P(A)\$ for constructing the likelihood function for the degradation data.
This degradation model was also proposed by Park & Padgett [14].
Because \$X_{t}\$ is strictly increasing in \$t\$, the probability that \$S>t\$ is obtained by  Using this, Park & Padgett [14] derived the exact pdf of \$S\$.
It is immediate that  Park & Padgett [14] do not consider \$P(A)\$ for constructing the likelihood for the degradation data.
It should be noted again that Padgett & Tomlinson [13], and Park & Padgett [14] used \$f_{A}(\cdot)\$ instead of \$f(\cdot\vert A)\$ by ignoring \$P(A)\$ as mentioned before.
These results improve and extend the work of Park & Padgett [14], and others as described earlier.

links.abstract: An analysis strategy (experimental and analytic) for extracting reliability information from the measured degradation of devices subjected to elevated stress is described. The strategy is applied to the estimation of the reliability of an integrated logic family that is a component of a new generation of submarine cables. The experiment consisted of monitoring several electrical parameters while aging the devices under elevated temperature. The authors model changes observed in one of these elec...

links.abstract: Based on a generalized cumulative damage approach with a stochastic process describing initial damage for a material specimen, a broad class of statistical models for material strength is developed. Plausible choices of stochastic processes for the initial damage include Brownian motion, geometric Brownian motion, and the gamma process; and additive & multiplicative cumulative damage functions are considered. The resulting general statistical model gives an accelerated test form of the inverse G...

context.text: The system failure time, considered as the first passage time to the threshold \$C\$, given by \$S=\inf\{u\vert X_{u}\geq C\}\$, has an inverse Gaussian distribution (see Chhikara & Folks [27]) with the pdf  where \$\mu=(C-x_{0})/\alpha\$, and \$\lambda=(C-x_{0})^{2}/\beta^{2}\$.
Then the above distribution is known to be close to the inverse Gaussian distribution with parameters \$\mu=C_{\beta}/\alpha\$ & \$\lambda=C_{\beta}^{2}/\alpha\$; see Chhikara & Folks [27].

context.text: To avoid this difficulty, they provided the approximate distribution of \$S\$ which is given by a form of the Birnbaum-Saunders distribution [28], where \$\alpha^{\ast}=1/\sqrt{C_{\beta}}\$, \$\beta^{\ast}=C_{\beta}/\alpha\$, and \$C_{\beta}=(C-x_{0})/\beta\$.
